title: Results Overview
text: This section presents the statistical findings from our analysis of voter turnout across six states from 1980 to 2024. We examined multiple socioeconomic and environmental factors to understand what drives electoral participation.

title: Results Overview
text:
Key Findings Summary

Partisan Context

Presidential Elections: Swing states show 5.47% higher turnout than Blue states (p = 0.0012)
Midterm Elections: Similar patterns observed but with weaker statistical significance
State political identity significantly influences participation



Economic Factors

Housing Price Index: High HPI states show 5% higher turnout in presidential elections (p < 0.001)
Unemployment: Modest relationship detected in midterm elections
Median Household Income: Group-level effects present but no specific pairwise differences



Crime Impact

Presidential Elections: Medium crime periods associated with higher turnout than high crime periods
Voter turnout 4-8 percentage points higher during low-crime era (2001-2024) vs. high-crime era (1986-2000)
Midterm Elections: No significant relationship detected



Weather Conditions

No significant impact on voter turnout in either presidential or midterm elections
Temperature accounts for less than 1% of turnout variation
Precipitation shows no association with participation rates



Time Series Forecasting
All three representative states (Florida, California, Michigan) forecast rising unemployment heading into 2026 midterm:

Florida: +1.62 percentage points
California: +0.78 percentage points
Michigan: +0.67 percentage points

title: Results Overview
text:
Detailed Results
Use the navigation menu above to explore detailed results for each category:

Partisan Party - State political affiliation and turnout
Economics - Unemployment, income, and housing price effects
Crime - Violent crime rates and electoral participation
Weather - Temperature and precipitation impacts
Time Series - ARIMA forecasting models and predictions

title: Results Overview
text:
Statistical Approach
All analyses were conducted separately for presidential and midterm elections to account for structural differences in turnout patterns. We employed multiple statistical techniques:

One-Way ANOVA and Welch’s ANOVA
Chi-Square Tests of Independence
Permutation Tests
Bootstrap Resampling
ARIMA Time Series Models

Significance was evaluated at α = 0.05 with appropriate corrections for multiple comparisons.

title: Time Series Forecasting
text: We conducted time series analysis to forecast unemployment rates for the 2026 midterm election across three representative states using ARIMA models fit to historical data from 1976 to 2024.

Stationarity Assessment


Code
# ADF test on original series
adf_fl <- adf.test(fl_ts)

# Differencing
fl_diff <- diff(fl_ts, differences = 1)
adf_fl_diff <- adf.test(fl_diff)

tibble(
  Series = c("Original", "After Differencing"),
  `ADF Statistic` = c(adf_fl$statistic, adf_fl_diff$statistic),
  `p-value` = c(round(adf_fl$p.value, 3), round(adf_fl_diff$p.value, 3)),
  Conclusion = c(
    ifelse(adf_fl$p.value < 0.05, "Stationary", "Non-stationary"),
    ifelse(adf_fl_diff$p.value < 0.05, "Stationary", "Non-stationary")
  )
) %>%
  kable(caption = "Stationarity Testing: Florida") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

Model Selection


Code
# Fit candidate models
fl_model1 <- Arima(fl_ts, order = c(0, 1, 1))
fl_model2 <- Arima(fl_ts, order = c(1, 1, 0))
fl_model3 <- Arima(fl_ts, order = c(1, 1, 1))
fl_model4 <- Arima(fl_ts, order = c(2, 1, 0))

# Auto ARIMA
fl_auto <- auto.arima(fl_ts, seasonal = FALSE)

tibble(
  Model = c("ARIMA(0,1,1)", "ARIMA(1,1,0)", "ARIMA(1,1,1)", "ARIMA(2,1,0)", "Auto ARIMA"),
  Specification = c("MA(1) with diff", "AR(1) with diff", "ARMA(1,1) with diff", "AR(2) with diff", paste0("ARIMA", paste0(arimaorder(fl_auto), collapse = ","))),
  AIC = c(AIC(fl_model1), AIC(fl_model2), AIC(fl_model3), AIC(fl_model4), AIC(fl_auto))
) %>%
  kable(caption = "Model Comparison: Florida", digits = 2) %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: Time Series Forecasting
text:
Comparative Analysis

Model Specifications

Florida & California: Both exhibit ARIMA(2,0,0) specifications, indicating comparable economic stability across partisan contexts
Michigan: ARIMA(0,1,0) reflects manufacturing-sector volatility, evidenced by large cyclical swings during the 1982, 2008, and 2020 recessions



Forecast Convergence
All three states forecast rising unemployment heading into 2026:

Largest increase: Florida (+1.62 percentage points)
Moderate increases: California (+1.4), Michigan (+0)

Despite historical differences, forecasts converge to similar levels (5.28% to 6.78%), though confidence intervals span 5.3 to 7.1 percentage points, reflecting considerable uncertainty.

title: Time Series Forecasting
text:
Implications

Limited Predictive Power for Turnout
Given the weak unemployment-turnout correlation identified earlier (p = 0.0217), these forecasts provide economic context but limited predictive power for voter participation.


Differential Predictability
The key finding concerns differential predictability:

Stable economies (Florida & California): Enable reliable forecasting
Volatile economy (Michigan): Complicates prediction and suggests swing state campaigns must account for greater economic uncertainty



2026 Context
All three states are entering the 2026 midterm with rising unemployment, which may influence campaign messaging around economic issues, though the direct effect on turnout appears modest based on our earlier analyses.

title: Time Series Forecasting
text:
Methodological Notes

Stationarity: Assessed via ADF test and ACF plots
Model selection: Manual specification + auto.arima comparison
Evaluation criteria: AIC, BIC, diagnostic checks
Forecasting horizon: 2025-2026
Confidence intervals: 95% level

title: Economic Factors Analysis
text: This section examines the relationship between macroeconomic variables (unemployment rate, median household income, and housing price index) and voter turnout in presidential and midterm elections.

title: Economic Factors Analysis
text:
Key Findings

Housing Price Index: High HPI states show 5% higher turnout in presidential elections (p < 0.001)
Unemployment: Modest relationship in midterm elections
Median Household Income: Group-level effects present but no specific pairwise differences

title: Economic Factors Analysis
text:
Assumption Testing

Midterm Elections
For midterm election years, assumption checks were conducted to evaluate the appropriateness of parametric analyses. Normality was assessed using residual diagnostics and Q-Q plots (Figures 11-13). Across all three economic variables, residuals appeared approximately normally distributed.


Code
# Create unemployment groups
econ_voter_midterm <- econ_voter_midterm %>%
  mutate(unemployment_group = ntile(Unemployment_Rate, 3))

# Fit ANOVA model
anova_midterm_unemp <- aov(normalized_vep_turnout ~ factor(unemployment_group), data = econ_voter_midterm)

# Q-Q plot
qqnorm(residuals(anova_midterm_unemp), main = "Q-Q Plot: Midterm Elections (Unemployment)")
qqline(residuals(anova_midterm_unemp), col = "red", lwd = 2)





Figure 11: Q-Q Plot - Midterm Voter Turnout by Unemployment Group






Code
# Create income groups
econ_voter_midterm <- econ_voter_midterm %>%
  mutate(income_group = ntile(Household_Income, 3))

# Fit ANOVA model
anova_midterm_income <- aov(normalized_vep_turnout ~ factor(income_group), data = econ_voter_midterm)

# Q-Q plot
qqnorm(residuals(anova_midterm_income), main = "Q-Q Plot: Midterm Elections (Income)")
qqline(residuals(anova_midterm_income), col = "red", lwd = 2)





Figure 12: Q-Q Plot - Midterm Voter Turnout by Income Group






Code
# Create HPI groups
econ_voter_midterm <- econ_voter_midterm %>%
  mutate(hpi_group = ntile(HPI, 3))

# Fit ANOVA model
anova_midterm_hpi <- aov(normalized_vep_turnout ~ factor(hpi_group), data = econ_voter_midterm)

# Q-Q plot
qqnorm(residuals(anova_midterm_hpi), main = "Q-Q Plot: Midterm Elections (HPI)")
qqline(residuals(anova_midterm_hpi), col = "red", lwd = 2)





Figure 13: Q-Q Plot - Midterm Voter Turnout by HPI Group




Levene’s Test Results (Midterm):


Code
# Levene's tests for all three variables
levene_unemp_mid <- leveneTest(normalized_vep_turnout ~ factor(unemployment_group), data = econ_voter_midterm)
levene_income_mid <- leveneTest(normalized_vep_turnout ~ factor(income_group), data = econ_voter_midterm)
levene_hpi_mid <- leveneTest(normalized_vep_turnout ~ factor(hpi_group), data = econ_voter_midterm)

tibble(
  Variable = c("Unemployment Rate", "Median Household Income", "Housing Price Index"),
  `p-value` = c(
    round(levene_unemp_mid$`Pr(>F)`[1], 5),
    round(levene_income_mid$`Pr(>F)`[1], 5),
    round(levene_hpi_mid$`Pr(>F)`[1], 4)
  ),
  Conclusion = c(
    ifelse(levene_unemp_mid$`Pr(>F)`[1] > 0.05, "Equal variances (use standard ANOVA)", "Unequal variances (use Welch's ANOVA)"),
    ifelse(levene_income_mid$`Pr(>F)`[1] > 0.05, "Equal variances (use standard ANOVA)", "Unequal variances (use Welch's ANOVA)"),
    ifelse(levene_hpi_mid$`Pr(>F)`[1] > 0.05, "Equal variances (use standard ANOVA)", "Unequal variances (use Welch's ANOVA)")
  )
) %>%
  kable(caption = "Levene's Test Results for Midterm Elections") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

Bonferroni Pairwise Tests:


Code
alpha_bonf <- 0.05 / 3

low_unemp <- econ_voter_midterm %>% filter(unemployment_group == 1) %>% pull(normalized_vep_turnout)
mid_unemp <- econ_voter_midterm %>% filter(unemployment_group == 2) %>% pull(normalized_vep_turnout)
high_unemp <- econ_voter_midterm %>% filter(unemployment_group == 3) %>% pull(normalized_vep_turnout)

tt_low_mid <- t.test(low_unemp, mid_unemp)
tt_low_high <- t.test(low_unemp, high_unemp)
tt_mid_high <- t.test(mid_unemp, high_unemp)

tibble(
  Comparison = c("Low vs Mid", "Low vs High", "Mid vs High"),
  `Mean Difference` = c(
    round(mean(low_unemp) - mean(mid_unemp), 2),
    round(mean(low_unemp) - mean(high_unemp), 2),
    round(mean(mid_unemp) - mean(high_unemp), 2)
  ),
  `Adjusted p-value` = c(
    round(tt_low_mid$p.value, 4),
    round(tt_low_high$p.value, 4),
    round(tt_mid_high$p.value, 4)
  )
) %>%
  kable(caption = "Bonferroni Pairwise Tests (Significance Level: 0.0167)") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: Economic Factors Analysis
text:
Summary

Housing affordability matters: High HPI predicts higher presidential turnout
Unemployment shows modest effects: Group-level relationship in midterms
Income effects are subtle: Present but no specific pairwise significance
Election type matters: Effects differ between presidential and midterm cycles

title: Socioeconomic and Structural Determinants for Voter Turnout in the U.S. Elections
text:
Voter turnout in the United States varies dramatically from state to state and election to election, raising questions about what actually drives people to the polls. Despite voting being a constitutional right that allows citizens to shape their government and communities, participation rates remain uneven. Some communities consistently turn out in high numbers while others see barely half of eligible voters show up, even in presidential elections.
The standard explanation centers on civic duty or political engagement, but that misses something. People are dealing with rent hikes, job instability, rising crime, the daily stress of making ends meet. The question becomes: do these real-world conditions actually influence whether people vote?
If cost of living jumps between election cycles, does turnout shift? If unemployment spikes, does participation change? The tension is whether voting behavior stays stable regardless of external circumstances or whether it responds to the conditions people are living through. If turnout is responsive to these pressures, then understanding participation requires identifying what tangible factors shape whether people make it to the polls.

title: Socioeconomic and Structural Determinants for Voter Turnout in the U.S. Elections
text:
Research Question
Do socioeconomic pressures like unemployment, housing affordability, crime rates, and cost of living predict voter turnout better than civic obligation alone?
We hypothesize that socioeconomic pressures create practical barriers to participation or shift how people prioritize political engagement when they’re dealing with economic strain. The central question is whether these external conditions have become stronger predictors of turnout than civic obligation alone.

title: Socioeconomic and Structural Determinants for Voter Turnout in the U.S. Elections
text:
Study Design

States Analyzed
We selected six states with different political leanings:

Red States: Florida, Utah
Blue States: California, New York
Swing States: Ohio, Michigan

This setup lets us see whether socioeconomic factors influence turnout the same way everywhere or if the effects depend on political context.


Time Period
1980-2024 spanning 23 elections (12 presidential, 11 midterm)
This covers multiple economic cycles, recessions, growth periods, and varying levels of political polarization. Spanning four decades means we can look at correlations between socioeconomic conditions and turnout at specific points in time and also see whether changes in these conditions between elections predict shifts in participation.

title: Socioeconomic and Structural Determinants for Voter Turnout in the U.S. Elections
text:
Variables

Dependent Variable
Voter Turnout - measured as the percentage of voting-eligible population (VEP) who cast ballots in each election


Independent Variables
Economic Indicators:

Median Household Income
Unemployment Rate
Housing Price Index (affordability measure)

Social Factors:

Violent Crime Rates (per 100,000 people)

Environmental Conditions:

Election Day Weather (temperature, precipitation)

Political Context:

State Political Affiliation (Red/Blue/Swing)
Election Type (Presidential vs. Midterm)

title: Socioeconomic and Structural Determinants for Voter Turnout in the U.S. Elections
text:
Analytical Approach
Our approach combines:

Correlation analysis to identify associations between socioeconomic factors and turnout
Hypothesis testing to compare turnout between groups (high vs. low income, high vs. low unemployment)
Time series analysis to examine whether changes in conditions between cycles predict turnout shifts

The goal is pinpointing trends that can predict whether a given election will see high or low turnout based on socioeconomic conditions.

Figure 5: Bootstrap Distribution - Presidential Voter Turnout (Crime Eras)

crime_voter_pres$crime_era <- ifelse(crime_voter_pres$Year < 2001, "High_crime_era", "Low_crime_era")

Figure 8: Permutation Distribution - Presidential Elections


Code
set.seed(5100)
n_permutations <- 10000

observed_cor_pres <- cor(weather_turnout_pres$tavg,
                         weather_turnout_pres$vep_turnout_rate,
                         use = "complete.obs")

permuted_cors_pres <- numeric(n_permutations)
for (i in 1:n_permutations) {
  shuffled_turnout <- sample(weather_turnout_pres$vep_turnout_rate)
  permuted_cors_pres[i] <- cor(weather_turnout_pres$tavg,
                               shuffled_turnout,
                               use = "complete.obs")
}

p_value_pres <- mean(abs(permuted_cors_pres) >= abs(observed_cor_pres))

tibble(correlation = permuted_cors_pres) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = correlation)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 50, fill = "steelblue", color = "black", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = observed_cor_pres, color = "red",
             linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 1.0) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -observed_cor_pres, color = "red",
             linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 1.0) +
  labs(title = "Permutation Distribution: Presidential Elections",
       subtitle = sprintf("Observed r = %.4f, p-value = %.4f",
                         observed_cor_pres, p_value_pres),
       x = "Correlation Coefficient",
       y = "Frequency") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12))








Figure 8





Permutation distribution of the correlation between Election Day temperature and voter turnout in presidential elections. The distribution is centered near zero, and the observed correlation falls within the null distribution, indicating no statistically significant linear relationship.

Figure 8: Permutation Distribution - Presidential Elections


Code
set.seed(5100)
n_permutations <- 10000

observed_cor_pres <- cor(weather_turnout_pres$tavg,
                         weather_turnout_pres$vep_turnout_rate,
                         use = "complete.obs")

permuted_cors_pres <- numeric(n_permutations)
for (i in 1:n_permutations) {
  shuffled_turnout <- sample(weather_turnout_pres$vep_turnout_rate)
  permuted_cors_pres[i] <- cor(weather_turnout_pres$tavg,
                               shuffled_turnout,
                               use = "complete.obs")
}

p_value_pres <- mean(abs(permuted_cors_pres) >= abs(observed_cor_pres))

tibble(correlation = permuted_cors_pres) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = correlation)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 50, fill = "steelblue", color = "black", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = observed_cor_pres, color = "red",
             linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 1.0) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -observed_cor_pres, color = "red",
             linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 1.0) +
  labs(title = "Permutation Distribution: Presidential Elections",
       subtitle = sprintf("Observed r = %.4f, p-value = %.4f",
                         observed_cor_pres, p_value_pres),
       x = "Correlation Coefficient",
       y = "Frequency") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12))








Figure 8





Permutation distribution of the correlation between Election Day temperature and voter turnout in presidential elections. The distribution is centered near zero, and the observed correlation falls within the null distribution, indicating no statistically significant linear relationship.

title: Conclusion
text: This study investigated whether socioeconomic and environmental factors predict voter turnout better than civic obligation alone. Our analysis of six states from 1980 to 2024 reveals that the answer is nuanced: some factors matter significantly, others show modest effects, and some conventional assumptions prove incorrect.

title: Conclusion
text:
Key Findings by Factor

Partisan Party
Our analysis proves that a state’s political “color” influences voter turnout in Presidential elections. Swing states showed a 5.47% higher turnout than Blue states (p = 0.0012), validated by both Welch’s ANOVA and Chi-Square tests. In Midterm elections, the relationship is significant but weaker. The gap between Swing and Blue states was 4.96%, but after Bonferroni correction, this did not meet the adjusted significance threshold.
Conclusion: State political identity plays a meaningful role in electoral participation, particularly in presidential contests.


Macroeconomics
Statistical testing revealed differential relationships between economic variables and turnout across election types:
Presidential Elections:

Housing Price Index: High HPI states reported 5% higher turnout (p < 0.001)
Median Household Income: Group-level effects present but no specific pairwise differences
Unemployment Rate: No statistically significant relationship

Midterm Elections:

Unemployment Rate: Modest group-level relationship (p = 0.0217), though pairwise tests inconclusive
Median Household Income: No significant relationship
Housing Price Index: No significant relationship

Conclusion: Housing affordability emerges as the strongest economic predictor of presidential turnout. Unemployment shows weak predictive power despite conventional assumptions.


Crime
Violent crime rates demonstrate distinct patterns across election types:
Presidential Elections - Significant Effects:

Medium crime periods showed higher turnout than high-crime periods (4.35 percentage points, p = 0.004)
Low-crime era (2001-2024) exhibited 4-8 percentage points higher turnout than high-crime era (1986-2000)
Bootstrap confidence interval: [4.04, 8.00]

Midterm Elections - No Effect:

No statistically significant relationship detected (ANOVA p = 0.642)
Bootstrap CI includes zero: [−1.14, 3.81]

Conclusion: Violent crime rates meaningfully influence presidential turnout but exhibit minimal influence on midterm participation. This distinction underscores the importance of election context.


Weather
Contrary to common assumptions, our analysis found no significant relationship between Election Day weather and voter turnout:

Temperature accounts for < 1% of turnout variation (R² = 0.0085 presidential, 0.0047 midterm)
Precipitation shows no association (Chi-Square p > 0.35 for both election types)
Permutation tests confirm observed correlations are consistent with random variation

Conclusion: Weather conditions do not meaningfully influence voter turnout and should not be considered a barrier to voting in the examined states and period.


Time Series Forecasting
ARIMA models forecast rising unemployment across all three representative states heading into 2026:

Florida (Red): +1.62 percentage points
California (Blue): +0.78 percentage points
Michigan (Swing): +0.67 percentage points

Key Finding: Florida and California exhibited comparable ARIMA(2,0,0) specifications despite opposing political contexts, indicating economic stability. Michigan’s simpler ARIMA(0,1,0) reflected manufacturing-sector volatility.
Conclusion: Given the weak unemployment-turnout correlation (p = 0.0217), these forecasts provide economic context but limited predictive power for voter participation. Stable economies enable reliable forecasting, while volatile economies complicate prediction for swing state campaigns.

title: Conclusion
text:
Theoretical Implications

Civic Duty vs. Responsive Participation
Our findings support a hybrid model:

Some support for responsive participation: Housing affordability, crime rates, and state political context significantly predict turnout
But with important caveats: Effects are modest (several percentage points), context-dependent (election type matters), and variable across factors

Voting behavior is neither purely stable civic duty nor purely responsive to material conditions. It appears to flex with certain socioeconomic pressures while remaining largely insulated from others.


What Matters and What Doesn’t
Factors That Significantly Predict Turnout:

State political affiliation (particularly swing vs. blue)
Housing price index (presidential elections)
Violent crime rates (presidential elections)

Factors With Weak or No Effects:

Weather conditions (contrary to conventional wisdom)
Unemployment rate (weak effects despite expectations)
Most economic factors in midterm elections

title: Conclusion
text:
Practical Implications

For Campaign Strategy

Resource Allocation: Higher baseline turnout in swing states validates intensive campaign resource deployment in competitive areas
Economic Messaging: Housing affordability significantly predicts presidential turnout—campaigns should prioritize cost-of-living concerns, particularly in high HPI states
Public Safety Context: Crime rates influence presidential participation. Campaigns may benefit from addressing public safety, especially during periods of concern
Weather-Proofing Unnecessary: GOTV efforts should not overweight weather-related mobilization concerns—weather is not a meaningful barrier



For Voter Mobilization Organizations

Economic conditions matter: Turnout responds to material circumstances voters face, particularly housing costs
Election type dependency: Factors influencing presidential turnout may not translate to midterms
Predictive modeling: Housing costs offer stronger predictive power than unemployment or income alone

title: Conclusion
text:
Limitations and Future Research

Current Limitations

Geographic Scope: Analysis limited to six states—may not generalize to all U.S. contexts
Temporal Window: Constrained by data availability (primarily 1980-2024)
Economic Metrics: Focused on three indicators (unemployment, income, HPI)—excludes CPI, savings, public expenditure
Aggregate Level: State-level analysis cannot capture within-state variation or individual-level behaviors



Future Research Opportunities

Expand geographic coverage to all 50 states for broader generalizability
Extend temporal range with historical data sources
Include additional economic indicators (CPI, consumer sentiment, debt levels, savings rates)
Incorporate cultural metrics (education rates, religious composition, health outcomes)
Analyze down-ballot races and local elections
Model interaction effects between multiple socioeconomic factors
Conduct individual-level analysis with voter file data to understand mechanisms

title: Conclusion
text:
Final Conclusion
This research demonstrates that socioeconomic conditions do influence voter turnout, but not uniformly across all factors or election types. Housing affordability and crime rates emerge as significant predictors in presidential elections, while state political context matters across both presidential and midterm contests. Surprisingly, weather conditions—often cited as barriers—show no meaningful relationship with participation.
The central tension posed at the outset—whether turnout stays stable regardless of external circumstances or responds to conditions voters face—resolves to: it depends on which conditions and which elections. Participation is neither purely stable nor purely responsive, but selectively responsive to certain socioeconomic pressures in particular electoral contexts.
For campaigns, the implication is clear: focus on housing costs and public safety in presidential years, recognize that swing state dynamics drive participation, and don’t worry about the weather. For researchers, the path forward involves expanding scope, incorporating additional metrics, and understanding the mechanisms through which certain factors influence participation while others do not.

title: Statistical Methods
text: Statistical analyses were conducted using voter turnout data alongside socioeconomic and environmental factors. All analyses were performed separately for presidential and midterm election years to account for structural differences in turnout patterns. The specific statistical methods employed varied based on the research question and the structure of the data.

title: Statistical Methods
text:
One-Way ANOVA Test
One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate the relationship between voter turnout and crime, economic, and weather-related factors. In each analysis, mean normalized voter turnout served as the dependent variable and was compared across categorical groupings derived from the independent variables of interest. This resulted in two one-way ANOVA models per independent variable: one for presidential elections and one for midterm elections.
For all one-way ANOVA models, independent variables were divided into tertiles, creating low, medium, and high groupings. The null hypothesis (H₀) stated that mean normalized voter turnout did not differ across groups, while the alternative hypothesis (Ha) stated that at least one group exhibited a statistically significant difference in mean voter turnout.

title: Statistical Methods
text:
Normality and Equal Variance Test
Prior to conducting one-way ANOVA, model assumptions were evaluated. Normality of residuals was assessed primarily through visual inspection of Q–Q plots of the ANOVA model residuals, which were examined for deviations in distributional shape, skewness, and tail behavior. In addition, the Shapiro–Wilk test was used as a supplementary diagnostic to statistically assess departures from normality.
Minor deviations from normality were considered acceptable given the sample sizes and the well-documented robustness of ANOVA to mild violations of the normality assumption.
Homogeneity of variance across groups was evaluated using Levene’s test, which assesses whether the variance of voter turnout differed across tertile groupings (low, medium, high). The null hypothesis for Levene’s test stated that variances were equal across groups, while the alternative hypothesis stated that at least one group exhibited unequal variance.

title: Statistical Methods
section: Welch’s One-Way ANOVA and Post-Hoc Testing
text:
Welch’s One-Way ANOVA and Post-Hoc Testing
When the assumption of homogeneity of variance was violated, as indicated by statistically significant Levene’s test results, Welch’s one-way ANOVA was employed in place of the standard one-way ANOVA. Welch’s ANOVA relaxes the equal-variance assumption and is more robust to unequal variances and sample sizes.
For models yielding statistically significant Welch’s ANOVA results, post-hoc pairwise comparisons were conducted using the Games–Howell procedure. This method is specifically designed for unequal variances and sample sizes and controls for Type I error without assuming homogeneity of variance. Post-hoc results were used to identify the specific group differences contributing to overall ANOVA significance.
All statistical tests were evaluated using a two-tailed significance level of α = 0.05.

title: Statistical Methods
text:
Chi-Square Test
The chi-square test of independence was employed to examine whether there was an association between categorical groupings of explanatory variables and voter turnout classification. Turnout was categorized as High or Low relative to normalized expected turnout levels, and was tested against categorical groupings derived from variables of interest, including environmental conditions and political context.
The null hypothesis (H₀) stated that turnout classification and the categorical grouping of the explanatory variable were independent, indicating no relationship between the factor under consideration and whether voter turnout was higher or lower than expected. The alternative hypothesis (H₁) stated that turnout classification and the explanatory variable were associated.
For each analysis, a contingency table was constructed comparing turnout classification (High/Low) with the categorical grouping of the independent variable. Turnout was classified as High when normalized turnout values exceeded zero (above the state’s average expected level) and Low when normalized turnout values were below zero. All contingency tables satisfied the chi-square test’s distributional assumptions, with expected cell frequencies exceeding the minimum threshold required for valid inference.

title: Statistical Methods
text:
Permutation Test
The permutation test evaluates the null hypothesis that there is no association between two variables by repeatedly shuffling one variable and recalculating the correlation coefficient. In this case, we looked at whether a linear relationship exists between continuous variables: average temperature and voter turnout rate.
The permutation test provides a distribution-free alternative that does not rely on normality assumptions about the underlying data distribution.
The null hypothesis for this test (H₀) states that there is no linear correlation between temperature and voter turnout in the population. The alternative hypothesis (HA) states that there is a linear relationship between temperature and turnout.

title: Statistical Methods
text:
Bootstrap Test
A bootstrap resampling procedure was employed to evaluate a pre–post comparison of mean normalized voter turnout surrounding a crime-based cutoff. Election years were divided into two periods defined by this cutoff, and the difference in mean normalized voter turnout between the two periods was used as the statistic of interest.
Bootstrap resampling was conducted by repeatedly sampling with replacement from the observed voter turnout data within each period and computing the mean difference across resampled datasets. This process generated an empirical sampling distribution of the mean difference, which was used to construct confidence intervals and assess the magnitude and direction of turnout changes across periods.
The bootstrap approach was selected as a nonparametric inference method that does not rely on assumptions of normality or equal variances and is well suited for historical comparisons involving unequal sample sizes and potential distributional irregularities.
The null hypothesis (H₀) stated that the mean normalized voter turnout did not differ between the pre- and post-cutoff periods. The alternative hypothesis (HA) stated that a difference in mean normalized voter turnout existed between the two periods.

title: Statistical Methods
text:
Time Series Analysis
Time series analysis was employed to forecast unemployment rates for the 2026 midterm election across three representative states: Florida (red state), California (blue state), and Michigan (swing state). ARIMA models were fit to historical unemployment data from 1976 to 2024 to predict future economic conditions that may influence voter turnout.

Stationarity Assessment
Stationarity was assessed using the Augmented Dickey-Fuller (ADF) test and autocorrelation function (ACF) plots. The null hypothesis for the ADF test stated that the series contained a unit root (non-stationary), while the alternative hypothesis stated that the series was stationary. When series were non-stationary (ADF p-value > 0.05), first-order differencing was applied to remove trend components before model fitting.


Model Selection
ARIMA(p,d,q) models combine autoregressive terms (p), differencing operations (d), and moving average terms (q). Model selection proceeded in two stages:

Manual specification of four candidate models based on ACF and PACF patterns
Systematic testing using the auto.arima algorithm

Models were compared using Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), with lower values indicating superior fit.


Model Diagnostics
Selected models underwent diagnostic evaluation using the sarima procedure, which assessed:

Standardized residuals for randomness
Residual ACF for remaining autocorrelation
Ljung-Box statistics to verify white noise properties (p > 0.05)

Model performance was validated against benchmark methods (naive and mean forecasts) using Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Mean Squared Error (MSE). Final models generated point forecasts and 95% confidence intervals for 2025 and 2026.
Classical seasonal decomposition was not applicable due to annual observation frequency (frequency = 1).

title: Statistical Methods
text:
Summary
Collectively, these methods were applied based on the scale and structure of each research question:

One-way ANOVA and Welch’s ANOVA for group-based comparisons of voter turnout across categorical factors
Chi-square tests for associations between categorical variables
Permutation tests to assess relationships between continuous variables
Bootstrap resampling for historical pre–post comparisons
Time series analysis to forecast future economic conditions based on historical patterns

Specific applications of each method are described in the Results section.

title: Crime Analysis
text:
We conducted multiple tests (ANOVA, Bonferroni t-tests, and bootstrap) for the crime data to examine if there are significant relationships between voter turnout and violent crime rates. The voter turnout data is split between Presidential and Midterm election cycles.
Research Question: Does an increase/decrease in crime lead to an increase/decrease in voter turnout, or does crime have no effect on turnout?

Bonferroni Pairwise Tests:


Code
# Extract VEP turnout for each violent crime group
low_violent <- crime_voter_pres %>% filter(violent_crime_group == 1) %>% pull(normalized_vep_turnout)
mid_violent <- crime_voter_pres %>% filter(violent_crime_group == 2) %>% pull(normalized_vep_turnout)
high_violent <- crime_voter_pres %>% filter(violent_crime_group == 3) %>% pull(normalized_vep_turnout)

# Bonferroni-corrected alpha
alpha_bonf <- 0.05 / 3

# Pairwise t-tests
ttest_low_mid <- t.test(low_violent, mid_violent, var.equal = FALSE)
ttest_low_high <- t.test(low_violent, high_violent, var.equal = FALSE)
ttest_mid_high <- t.test(mid_violent, high_violent, var.equal = FALSE)

# Create results table
tibble(
  Comparison = c("Low vs Mid", "Low vs High", "Mid vs High"),

    sprintf("%.2f", mean(mid_violent, na.rm = TRUE) - mean(high_violent, na.rm = TRUE))
  ),
  `Adjusted p-value` = c(

Bootstrap Analysis: High- vs. Low-Crime Eras
Violent crime rates show a clear temporal distinction before and after 2001. We applied bootstrap resampling to compare mean normalized voter turnout between:

High-crime era: 1986–2000
Low-crime era: 2001–2024



Code
# Read crime data including United States
crime_all <- read_csv("data/processed-data/crime_data_yearly_clean.csv") %>%
  filter(!(State == "Florida" & Year == 1988))

# Plot with all states including United States
ggplot(crime_all, aes(x = Year, y = violent_crime_rate, color = State)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.0) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "United States" = "black",
    "California" = "#E69F00",
    "Florida" = "#F0E442",
    "Michigan" = "#56B4E9",
    "New York" = "#CC79A7",
    "Ohio" = "#009E73",
    "Utah" = "#D55E00"
  )) +
  labs(
    title = "Violent Crime Breakdown by Offense Type",
    x = "Year",
    y = NULL
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14),
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.title = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", fill = NA, linewidth = 1),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )





Figure 4: Violent Crime Breakdown by Offense Type






Code
# Create crime era variable
crime_voter_pres$crime_era <- ifelse(crime_voter_pres$Year < 2001, "High_crime_era", "Low_crime_era")

high_era <- crime_voter_pres$normalized_vep_turnout[crime_voter_pres$crime_era == "High_crime_era"]
low_era <- crime_voter_pres$normalized_vep_turnout[crime_voter_pres$crime_era == "Low_crime_era"]

# Bootstrap resampling
set.seed(100)
boot_diff_pres <- replicate(5000, {
  mean(sample(low_era, replace = TRUE)) -
  mean(sample(high_era, replace = TRUE))
})

ci_pres <- quantile(boot_diff_pres, c(0.025, 0.975))




Code
hist(boot_diff_pres, breaks = 30,
     main = "Bootstrap Distribution: Presidential Elections",
     xlab = "Difference in Means (Low - High Crime Era)",
     col = "steelblue", border = "black")
abline(v = ci_pres, col = "red", lty = 2, lwd = 2)
legend("topright", legend = "95% CI", col = "red", lty = 2, lwd = 2)





Figure 5: Bootstrap Distribution of Mean Presidential Turnout Difference (Low – High Crime Era)




Using 5,000 bootstrap resamples, we estimated the mean difference and constructed a 95% confidence interval.
Bootstrap Results:

95% CI: [4.04, 8]
Conclusion: Reject null hypothesis

Presidential elections during the low-crime era exhibit approximately 4.04 to 8 percentage points higher normalized voter turnout compared to elections during the high-crime era.

title: Partisan Party Analysis
text: Just as living in a specific state influences individual judgment, it also affects aggregate voter turnout. This section examines the relationship between turnout and state ‘color’ (Red, Blue, or Swing). We ran separate tests for Presidential and Midterm elections, utilizing ANOVA, pairwise t-tests with Bonferroni correction, and Chi-Square tests.

    round(pairwise_midterm$p.value["blue", "red"], 2),
    round(pairwise_midterm$p.value["purple", "red"], 2),
    round(pairwise_midterm$p.value["purple", "blue"], 2)
  )
) %>%
  kable(caption = "Bonferroni Pairwise Tests (Significance Level: 0.0166)") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: Partisan Party Analysis
text:
Summary

Presidential Elections: Strong evidence that state political affiliation influences turnout, particularly swing states vs. blue states
Midterm Elections: Similar patterns observed but with weaker pairwise significance
State political identity plays a meaningful role in electoral participation

title: Weather Analysis
text: We conducted two hypothesis tests (chi-square and permutation test) to examine the relationship between Election Day weather conditions and voter turnout, analyzing presidential and midterm elections separately.

title: Weather Analysis
section: Permutation Test: Temperature and Turnout Correlation
text:
Permutation Test: Temperature and Turnout Correlation
The permutation test examined whether the average election day temperature had a linear relationship with the voter turnout rate.

Presidential Elections
Results:

Pearson correlation (r): 0.092328
Permutation p-value: 0.449700
R²: 0.0085 (< 1% variance explained)

We fail to reject the null hypothesis (p > 0.05), indicating no statistically significant linear correlation between temperature and voter turnout in presidential elections. Temperature explains less than one percent of the variation in turnout.


Midterm Elections
Results:

Pearson correlation (r): 0.068752
Permutation p-value: 0.587800
R²: 0.0047 (< 1% variance explained)

We fail to reject the null hypothesis (p > 0.05), indicating no significant linear correlation between temperature and voter turnout in midterm elections. The variance explained is minimal.
Looking at the permutation distributions (Figures 9 & 10 in Appendix) for both presidential and midterm elections, the observed correlation coefficients fall within the range of expected values and are centered near zero, indicating that the observed correlations are consistent with random variation and not evidence of a systematic relationship.

title: Weather Analysis
text:
Summary
All four tests failed to achieve statistical significance. This uniform null result across both methodological approaches and both election types provides strong evidence that:

Election Day weather does not meaningfully influence voter turnout in the states and time period examined
Weather should not be considered a meaningful barrier to voting in elections
Temperature accounts for less than 1% of turnout variation
Precipitation (wet vs. dry conditions) shows no association with participation

Conclusion: Contrary to conventional wisdom, weather conditions have no significant impact on voter turnout.

title: Socioeconomic and Structural Determinants for Voter Turnout in the U.S. Elections
text:
Voter turnout in the United States varies dramatically from state to state and election to election, raising questions about what actually drives people to the polls. Despite voting being a constitutional right that allows citizens to shape their government and communities, participation rates remain uneven. Some communities consistently turn out in high numbers while others see barely half of eligible voters show up, even in presidential elections.
The standard explanation centers on civic duty or political engagement, but that misses something. People are dealing with rent hikes, job instability, rising crime, the daily stress of making ends meet. The question becomes: do these real-world conditions actually influence whether people vote?
If cost of living jumps between election cycles, does turnout shift? If unemployment spikes, does participation change? The tension is whether voting behavior stays stable regardless of external circumstances or whether it responds to the conditions people are living through. If turnout is responsive to these pressures, then understanding participation requires identifying what tangible factors shape whether people make it to the polls.
